„Äê

#‚Äã519 ‚Äî August 20, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

üèñÔ∏è If you missed last week's issue, don't worry - you didn't. I took a week off for a summer break, but now we're back ;-) Thanks to everyone who sent in links for us to check¬†out.
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Go 1.23 Released ‚Äî We‚Äôve been hearing about (and linking to) 1.23 for weeks in its various pre-release guises, but now it's here. You could call 1.23 a 'major minor' release, as it's mostly a gentle step forward but with some new features, like for range iteration and tooling additions (including the now opt-in telemetry system). Head to the official release notes for all the¬†details.

The Go Team

üí° For a more practical look at language improvements, don't forget Anton Zhiyanov's fantastic interactive release notes and¬†examples.

Structs are Copied on Assignment (and Other Things About Go I'd Missed) ‚Äî This gotcha likely catches many new-to-intermediate gophers, along with the other issues Julia also mentions. By the way, these are based on a few of the 100 Go Mistakes and How to Avoid Them site and¬†book.

Julia Evans

A Complete Introduction to Containers ‚Äî Join Brian Holt for this extensive video course covering the now industry standard approach for developing and deploying apps. You'll learn about core container technology, Docker Images, multi-container projects, and much¬†more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

‚ñ∂¬†¬†12 Talks from GopherCon UK 2024 ‚Äî GopherCon UK took place just a few days ago, but you can already enjoy a variety of talks including Matt Boyle on debugging Go apps, JesuÃÅs Espino digging into Go‚Äôs runtime, Beth Anderson on AI, and Google‚Äôs Michael Pratt look at profile guided¬†optimization. We'll feature more talks in future issues as we watch them, as there's a lot of gold in¬†here.

GopherCon UK

üí° If you want to get more of a feel for what the event was like, Jamie Tanna did a write up of the GopherCon UK 2024 experience.

HTTP/1.0 From Scratch ‚Äî We recently featured Kevin‚Äôs HTTP/0.9 From Scratch, a first step into reimplementing the basics of HTTP, step by step, in Go. Now we get to fast forward five years to 1996 and HTTP/1.0 which introduced things like the POST action, status codes, and content¬†negotiation.

Kevin McDonald

'An Unordered List of Things I Miss in Go' ‚Äî A solid list with some doable and not-so-doable items. On the doable side, there are ordered maps and default arguments. On the not-so-doable, null/nilability is a long-time contentious subject that likely would break backward¬†compatibility.

kokada

Go Maps Explained: How Key-Value Pairs Are Actually Stored ‚Äî A comprehensive, illustrated tutorial to how things are represented under the¬†hood.

Phuong Le

üõ† Code & Tools

go-vcr 4.0: Record and Replay Your HTTP Interactions ‚Äî Record and replay API interactions for faster, deterministic testing of potentially flaky endpoints ‚Äì here‚Äôs the v4.0 changelog. (If you‚Äôve used Ruby, you might recognize its inspiration: the popular VCR¬†library.)

Marin Atanasov Nikolov

GoNB: A Go Notebook Kernel for Jupyter ‚Äî Notebooks make it easy to do literate programming where you see results immediately like a REPL but with persistence and control over the source code. Common in Python, GoNB brings Go into the picture too. The latest release adds Jupytext support.

Jan Pfeifer

FusionAuth. Auth Built for Devs, by Devs ‚Äî Choose self-hosting or cloud, scale from 10 to 10 million users, and enjoy unlimited IDPs. Trusted by industry leaders with 10M+¬†downloads.

FusionAuth sponsor

Pie 2.9: A Utility Library for Dealing with Slices ‚Äî Ways to work with slices with a focus on type safety, performance and immutability. Now with a a new UniqueStable operation.

Elliot Chance

Lo: A Lodash-Style Library for Go 1.18+ ‚Äî Inspired by JavaScript‚Äôs Lodash and brings similar utility methods for working with slices, maps, and¬†more.

Samuel Berthe

kubetrim: Trim Your KUBECONFIG Automatically ‚Äî Takes your kubeconfig and trims out all the old / unused clusters and¬†contexts.

Alex Ellis

  • Bubble Tea 0.27 ‚Äì The powerful, popular TUI framework adds support for programmatically suspending and resuming¬†programs.

  • GoLand 2024.2 ‚Äì The latest release of JetBrains' popular commercial Go¬†IDE.

  • Pion TURN 4.0 ‚Äì Toolkit for building TURN clients and¬†servers.

  • GoReleaser 2.2 ‚Äì Build/release binaries for multiple¬†platforms.

  • wazero 1.8 ‚Äì Zero dependency WebAssembly runtime for¬†Go.

  • NATS.go 1.37 ‚Äì Go client for the NATS messaging¬†system.

  • gofumpt 0.7 ‚Äì A stricter gofmt.

item.title: „ÄêChannels that channel channels?„ÄëÊ∏†ÈÅìÔºåÊ∏†ÈÅìÔºåÊ∏†ÈÅìÔºü
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã520 ‚Äî August 27, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Range Over Function Types in Go 1.23 ‚Äî Go 1.23 was released just two weeks ago with one of the headline features being improvements to iteration, principally for/range support over function types. There‚Äôs a lot more to it than that, though, and Ian rounds up everything, complete with examples and¬†guidance.

Ian Lance Taylor

TinyGo 0.33.0: The Go Compiler for 'Small Places' ‚Äî TinyGo is a fantastic LLVM-based Go implementation targeting use cases like microcontrollers and WebAssembly. v0.33.0 brings it up to Go 1.23 standards, adds WASI preview 2 support, and¬†more.

TinyGo Team

WorkOS: The Modern Identity Platform for B2B¬†SaaS ‚Äî WorkOS is a modern identity platform for B2B SaaS, offering flexible and easy-to-use APIs to integrate SSO, SCIM, and RBAC in minutes instead of months. It's trusted by hundreds of high-growth startups such as Perplexity, Vercel, Drata, and¬†Webflow.

WorkOS sponsor

The 4-chan Go Programmer (or Sending Channels Over¬†Channels) ‚Äî No, not that '4chan.' Zach looks into the idea of using channels to pass other channels around, and takes it to the extreme of creating channels that channel channels that channel channels that channel channels. I need to go for a lie¬†down..

Zach Musgrave

sync.Pool and the Mechanics Behind It ‚Äî What sync.Pool is all about, how it‚Äôs used, what‚Äôs going on under the hood, and everything else you might want to know, complete with helpful¬†illustrations.

Phuong Le

üìÑ Designing a Robust Integration Test Suite for Convoy‚Äôs Data Plane with TestContainers Oluwalana and Mekiliuwa (Convoy)

üìÑ 'Go is My Hammer, and Everything is a Nail' ‚Äì You can use Go for¬†everything. Markus W√ºstenberg

üìÑ How Go's Testing Harness Works ‚Äì What happens when you run go¬†test? Matt Proud

üìÑ Using Functional Options Instead of Method Chaining Jon Calhoun

üõ† Code & Tools

sqlite-vec: A Vector Search Extension for SQLite ‚Äî If using a dedicated vector storage database is beyond your immediate requirements, you can now use SQLite for the task. While this is an SQLite extension, it‚Äôs easy to use with numerous languages, including Go, as shown¬†here.

Alex Garcia

moq: An Interface Mocking Tool for go generate ‚Äî A tool that generates a struct from any interface. The struct can be used in test code as a mock of the interface. Now supports imported type¬†aliases.

Mat Ryer

Streamline Your Product Delivery with monday dev ‚Äî From ideation to launch, monday dev makes product delivery faster and simpler, all in one¬†place.

monday dev sponsor

Permify 1.0: Open Source Authorization as a Service ‚Äî A long standing Go-powered system for building fine-grained authorization systems, inspired by Google‚Äôs Zanzibar. Get started with the intro¬†guide.

Permify

cast 1.7: Safe and Easy Casting from One Type to Another ‚Äî It‚Äôs as easy as using ToString, ToInt, ToTime, and¬†more.

Steve Francia

go-github v64.0: A Go Client for the GitHub v3 API ‚Äî For the REST API. For the v4 GraphQL API use this¬†instead.

Google

Dbmate: A Lightweight, Framework-Agnostic Database Migration Tool ‚Äî Written in Go but can be used alongside database-using apps written in any language. Supports MySQL, Postgres, SQLite, ClickHouse, BigQuery, and¬†Spanner.

Adrian Macneil

üì∞¬†Classifieds

Dragonfly (25k GitHub stars) is a modern Redis replacement. Organizations that switch to Dragonfly can reduce infrastructure costs by 80%.

Boost your PostgreSQL skills with Redgate‚Äôs 101 webinar series of easy-to-follow, expert hosted sessions. It‚Äôs PostgreSQL, simplified.

  • go-rest-api-example ‚Äì Template for an enterprise-ready REST API¬†microservice.

  • Glow 2.0 ‚Äì Markdown renderer for the¬†terminal.

  • Dynamo 2.2 ‚Äì Expressive Amazon DynamoDB client¬†library.

  • üíÑ Charm Lip Gloss 0.13 ‚Äì Style definitions for rendering nice terminal¬†layouts. It can now render¬†trees¬†too!

  • GoWrap 1.4 ‚Äì Tool to generate decorators for Go¬†interfaces.

  • Buf 1.38 ‚Äì CLI tool for working with Protocol¬†Buffers.

  • c-for-go 1.3 ‚Äì Automatic C-Go bindings generator.

  • Go OpenAI 1.29 ‚Äì An OpenAI API wrapper¬†library.

  • Bubbles 0.19 ‚Äì TUI components for Bubble¬†Tea.

  • netlink 1.3 ‚Äì Simple Netlink library for Go.

üéÅ And one for fun..

„Äê

#‚Äã517 ‚Äî July 30, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

Go Weekly

Cogent Core: A New GUI Framework for Go ‚Äî A new GUI framework with a ‚Äúcode once and run everywhere‚Äù promise for multiple platforms. It aims to be simpler to use than Gio and more powerful than Fyne. Curiously, Cogent‚Äôs web site itself is built in the framework and compiled to WASM to work on the Web. There‚Äôs also ‚ñ∂Ô∏è¬†a quick screencast pitching you on the¬†framework.

Kai O'Reilly and Randy O'Reilly

Go Features by Version (or What's in Which Go) ‚Äî A list of features and the versions in which they first appeared. Proof, if any were needed, that the progress made to Go isn't slowing down. (And if you want to get up to speed with Go 1.23, here are the notes for¬†you.)

Anton Zhiyanov

Render is Your Fastest Path to Production ‚Äî Whatever your stack you can build, deploy quickly, update and confidently scale your apps with ease, from the first to the billionth user. Start building with Render for free ‚Äî the modern cloud for¬†devs.

Render sponsor

Build Your Own SMTP Server in Go ‚Äî The actual code here isn‚Äôt low level, but it's a good practical guide to some of the technologies around sending e-mail, like SMTP, DKIM, and SPF. The go-smtp library ultimately does the heavy¬†lifting.

Alexis Bouchez

What‚Äôs New in Go 1.23: Iterators and reflect.Value.Seq ‚Äî Carlana explains four of the functions around generic custom iteration that she proposed, comparing the new code to something she wrote ten(!) years ago using channels. If 2022 was all about generics, is 2024 the year of¬†iterators?

Carlana Johnson

Learn Go with Tests: A Refactoring Checklist ‚Äî The popular Learn Go with Tests guide gains a new chapter that gets you thinking about refactoring, when it makes sense to do it, and some of the basic¬†techniques.

Chris James

The Union of Finite Automata, Explained ‚Äî Tim found existing explanations to be overly academic, so set out to explain the concept with a little¬†Go.

Tim Bray

Merge Go Code 10x Faster at Quality with AI-Driven Code¬†Reviews ‚Äî AI-first pull request reviewer that offers context-aware, line-by-line feedback and smart chat. Get a 7-day free trial. Free for OSS¬†projects.

CodeRabbit sponsor

üìÑ Parsing Protobuf Definitions with Tree-sitter ‚Äì If you need to go a few steps beyond what protoc can¬†do. Karl Matthias

üìÑ Highlights from Git 2.46 Taylor Blau (GitHub)

üõ† Code & Tools

Ollama 0.3: Quickly Run Large Language Models ‚Äî Ollama is an increasingly significant Go-powered tool in the LLM world (that uses llama.cpp behind the scenes) that makes it easy to run large language models. Recent releases have added concurrency, Llama 3.1 support, and, now, tool¬†calling.

Ollama Team

betteralign 0.5: Make Your Programs Use Less Memory.. Maybe ‚Äî A tool to detect structs that could use less memory. It‚Äôs a fork of Go‚Äôs fieldalignment tool that skips generated or test files, skips specially marked structs or those with anonymous fields, doesn‚Äôt drop comments, and similar DX¬†enhancements.

Dinko Korunic

üì∞¬†Classifieds

üö®Prevent data breaches before they happen! Secure your Go app on AWS with LocalOps‚Äô proven AWS security checklist. Download now and protect your data instantly!

Boost your PostgreSQL skills with Redgate‚Äôs 101 webinar series of easy-to-follow, expert hosted sessions. It‚Äôs PostgreSQL, simplified.

‚öôÔ∏é Zeppelin ‚Äì A Go-powered Minecraft 1.21 server. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù asks the README. ‚ÄúWhy not,‚Äù comes the¬†reply. Various Contributors

‚öôÔ∏é Reed-Solomon ‚Äì Fast Reed-Solomon erasure¬†coding. Klaus Post

‚öôÔ∏é Circumflex ‚Äì A terminal UI for Hacker News. Ben Sadeh

  • FerretDB 1.23 ‚Äì It's like MongoDB, but on top of Postgres or¬†SQLite.

  • go-yaml 1.12.0 ‚Äì YAML processing for Go with more¬†features.

  • Baur 5.0 ‚Äì Go-powered incremental task runner for¬†monorepos.

  • eBPF 0.16 ‚Äì Pure-Go library to work with eBPF¬†programs.

  • Goa 3.18 ‚Äì DSL for building¬†microservices.

üéÅ And one for fun..

Editor: A Source Code Editor in Pure Go ‚Äî Curiously billing itself as a ‚Äúsimple but advanced source code editor‚Äù, it works on Linux, Windows and macOS (under X server) and certainly has that old school Unix vibe going¬†on. Clearly a serious labor of love after some seven years of¬†development.

Jorge Miguel Pinto

item.title: „ÄêBye Russ, but also hi Russ„ÄëÂÜçËßÅÊãâÊñØÔºå‰ΩÜ‰πüÂó®ÊãâÊñØ
item.description:
„Äê

#‚Äã518 ‚Äî August 6, 2024

Unsub¬†¬†|¬†¬†Web¬†Version

üèñÔ∏è Hi! We're taking next week off for a brief summer break. We'll be back with our next issue on August 20. Also, if possible, can you click an item or two? We're going to be doing some 'list cleaning' soon and it's helpful to know if you're still keen to receive the newsletter¬†‚Äì thanks!¬†:-)
__
Peter Cooper, your editor

Go Weekly

Russ Cox Steps Down as Tech Lead of Go ‚Äî Russ has been instrumental in many of Go‚Äôs developments having led the project for 12 years, but it‚Äôs time for a change with Austin Clements taking his position. But Russ isn‚Äôt leaving the Go world. Indeed, he's already deep into a new project (see¬†next)..

Russ Cox

Oscar: An Open-Source Contributor Agent Architecture ‚Äî As Russ steps away as Go tech lead, he‚Äôs stepping into more work on Oscar, an AI agent system to help maintain open-source projects. The first bot, Gaby, is already up and running on Go‚Äôs issue tracker, with more to¬†come.

Russ Cox

Go! Unlock Your Tech Potential with Ardan Labs Consulting ‚Äî Struggling with skill gaps, development speed or complex tech challenges? Ardan Labs specializes in Go, Rust, Docker and K8s to accelerate your software development, optimize architecture, and manage tech debt. Let us supercharge your¬†team!

Ardan Labs Consulting sponsor

What's the Best Static Analysis Tool for Go? ‚Äî Static analysis can be a valuable part of an app‚Äôs quality toolchain, run by both developers and pipelines. But there are many options, official and otherwise, so which to choose? The answer is (kinda) all of¬†them‚Ä¶?

Nick Tobey (DoltHub)

A 10 Week Go Backend Engineer Onboarding Plan ‚Äî Stream has published the onboarding program they use for Go developers, which covers the basics of Go, databases, HTTP, and more. This is a great idea and sets expectations if you‚Äôre looking for¬†work.

Stream

Did You Know About Instruments? ‚Äî Instruments is a macOS app that allows you to create various traces and profiles of running applications. It offers quite the toolset, as indicated by Thorsten‚Äôs palpable¬†enthusiasm.

Thorsten Ball

Implementing HTTP/0.9 from Scratch ‚Äî The first instalment of a ‚ÄúHTTP from Scratch‚Äù series digging into the history of the protocol underpinning the¬†Web.

Kevin McDonald

üì∫ 5 Levels of Go Error Handling RageCageCodes

üõ† Code & Tools

approf: A Native macOS App for pprof ‚Äî An app experience for viewing the results from pprof profiling that includes drag/drop, reordering, light/dark mode, and saved¬†sessions.

Moderato

Glamour: Stylesheet-based Markdown Rendering for Your CLI¬†Apps ‚Äî Glamour lets you render simple Markdown from your app but then have styles applied to it so that it looks more colorful and elegant once it lands in the¬†terminal. Another great piece of work from the folks at Charm.

Charm

Your Fastest Path to Production ‚Äî Build, deploy, and scale your apps with unparalleled ease ‚Äì from your first user to your¬†billionth.

Render sponsor

mimetype: Library for Detecting MIME Types and Extensions ‚Äî Supporting 173 different types, you pass in binary data, a data stream or filename and, hopefully, find out what type of data you‚Äôre working¬†with.

Gabriel Vasile

go-sqlbuilder: A Flexible SQL String Builder Library ‚Äî Originally focused on MySQL and Postgres, it now supports SQL Server, SQLite, CQL, and more, too. Lets you use structs as a ‚Äòlight weight ORM‚Äô, and now also supports Common Table Expression and¬†ILIKE.

Huan Du

Minimock: A Tool to Generate Mocks from Interface Declarations ‚Äî Generates statically typed mocks and helpers, is fully integrated with the testing package, and supports¬†generics.

Juno Inc.

  • River 0.11 ‚Äì Fast and reliable Postgres-powered background jobs for¬†Go.

  • env 11.2 ‚Äì Zero dependency way to parse env variables into¬†structs.

  • Dgraph 24.0 - Native GraphQL database with a graph¬†backend.

  • üáØüáµ Kagome 2.10 ‚Äì Japanese morphological¬†analyzer.

  • Resty 2.14 ‚Äì Simple HTTP and REST client¬†library.

  • webdav 5.1 ‚Äì Standalone WebDAV¬†server.

  • GoBGP 3.29 ‚Äì BGP implementation in¬†Go.

As mentioned earlier, we're taking a week off and will be back on August 20.

If you didn't find anything to click in this issue, how about enjoying ‚ñ∂Ô∏è¬†this¬†particularly high quality 1950s-themed attempt at the classic Steamed Hams gag from The Simpsons? üòÑ
